STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 14, 2020
Kelli Arrendondo
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Muskegon
#125
1095 Third Street
Muskegon, MI 49441-1976
RE: License #: CB610201023
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Muskegon
#125
1095 Third Street
Muskegon, MI 49441-1976
Dear Ms. Arrendondo:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on July 9, 2020.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
ISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of ISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Repeat violations need explanation of why previous corrective action plan
was not successful.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Jessica VandenHeuvel, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(616) 204-6992
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
Two of three adoptive family evaluations reviewed were not completed within 60
days as required.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.19 Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. IF the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up action s to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Six of six open foster care case files reviewed lacked the required signatures on the
parent agency agreement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED-Previous Citation ISEP 6.33
Renewal Report dated 6/19/19, CAP approval date 6/26/19
Interim Report dated 7/18/18, CAP approval date 8/3/18
ISEP 6.16 Supervisory Oversight
Supervisors shall meet a least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status of progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the supervisor
has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the
monthly meeting.
4

Four of eight open foster care case files reviewed lacked documentation of monthly
supervision as required.
ISEP 6.21 Visits, Worker-Child
(a)Each child in foster care shall be visited by a caseworker at
least two time per month during the child’s first two months of
placement in an initial or new placement, and at least one time
per month thereafter. At least on e visit each month shall take
place at the child’s placement location and shall include a
private meeting between the child and the caseworker.
In three of three open foster care case files reviewed where a youth was initially
placed or replaced, the file lacked documentation of the caseworker visiting the
youth at least two times in the first two months as required.
Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed lacked documentation of monthly
visits between the worker and child in subsequent months as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED-Previous Citation ISEP 722-6H
Renewal Report dated 6/19/19, CAP approval date 6/26/19
Interim Report dated 7/18/18, CAP approval date 8/3/18
ISEP 6.22 Visits, Worker-Parent
(a)For each child in foster care with a permanency goal of
reunification, the child’s caseworker shall have face-to-face
contacts with the child’s parent(s) as follows:
(1) for the first month the child is in care, two face-to-face
contact with each parent, at least one of which must occur in the
parent’s place of residence.
(2) for each subsequent month, at least one face-to-face contact
with each parent and phone contact as needed, with at least on
contact in each three-month period occurring in the parent’s
place of residence.
Four of six open foster care case files reviewed with a goal of reunification lacked
documentation of monthly contact with the parent as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED-Previous Citation ISEP 6.40 and FOM 722-6H
Renewal Report dated 6/19/19, CAP approval date 6/26/19
Interim Report dated 7/18/18, CAP approval date 8/3/18
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements except
for the following:
5

FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
Signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
Four of six open foster care case files reviewed lacked the required caregiver
signatures, which would indicate their involvement in the plan development.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Report dated 6/19/19, CAP approval date 6/26/19
Interim Report dated 7/18/18, CAP approval date 8/3/18
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Upload of Activity Report DHS-1105 within 7 days.
Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed lacked the FTM Activity Report
within MiSACWIS.
SRM 200 Fingerprints
Controlled Area Requirement
Electronic and physical CW-CHRI media must be securely
stored within physically secure locations or controlled areas.
Access to such media is restricted to authorized personnel only
and secured at all times when not in use or under the
supervision of an authorized personnel.
During the onsite inspection, the file cabinet containing CHRI was not locked allowing
non-authorized personnel access to CHRI information.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Report dated 7/18/18, CAP approval date 8/3/18
FOM 722-3 Placement Selection and Standards
Placement Exception Request
6

One of one open foster care case file reviewed requiring a residential placement
exception request was not completed timely as required.
Two of three open foster care case file reviewed requiring a sibling split placement
exception request was not completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Report dated 6/19/19, CAP approval date 6/26/19
FOM 722-6 Case Planning
Engaging the Incarcerated Parent
In cases where reunification is the permanency goal, the case-
worker must engage the parent in the case service plan regardless
of how long that parent will be incarcerated.
The caseworker must make monthly contact with the incarcerated
parent through face-to-face contact, letter, email, or phone contact
One of one open foster care case file reviewed with a parent that was incarcerated
lacked documentation of the agencies efforts to engage the parent in the parent
agency treatment plan.
FOM 801 Health Services for Children in Foster Care
Medical Passport requirements.
Four of eight open foster care case files reviewed lacked the medical passport being
completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Report dated 6/19/19, CAP approval date 6/26/19
Interim Report dated 7/18/18, CAP approval date 8/3/18
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not in need of technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not in need of consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
7

The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The first was in response to the Renewal
Inspection. The second was in response to Special Investigation 2020C223011
where a complaint was received stating the agency changed placement of a youth
without following policy requirements. The agency was found in non-compliance for
R 400.12405 Change of Placement as the agency informed the foster mother via
telephone of the planned placement change, and had the foster mother sign the
Notification of Move (DHS-30). However, the agency was not in compliance as they
did not provide the foster parent with a written notice as required. The agency
developed a corrective action plan that was appropriate and implemented as verified
with a random review of case files during this audit.
Interviews were completed with staff during the inspection. All staff reported an
increase in confidence, structure, and guidance by administration during this period
under review. A new Program Manager was hired, promoting within the agency that
lead to consistency. During interviews with licensing, adoption, and foster care staff
they all reported good communication and understanding of job requirements. Staff
reported the agency communicates consistently with policy changes and provides
ample opportunities for growth and training.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1
Concern: The basement has a sliding glass door that leads to the pond located
behind the home. There is no type of alarm on the door.
Resolution: Licensing staff verified on 2/17/2020 a lock on the door leading down to
the basement and the key is located out of reach of the children and only the
caregivers know where it is located. Also, bells are located on the door handle to
signal to caregivers in the event that the children were trying to access the
basement. Bells continued to be located on the other door leading to the outside.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
July 9, 2020
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Licensing Consultant
8

Approved By:
July 14, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
